Some things I built

Fordham PD

Fordham People Watcher (naming is not my strongest skill) is a device that detects the capacity of a room using a Raspberry Pi and multiple detectors like motion, humidity, and temperature. The readings are then posted to a website that students can use.

Hardware Raspberry Pi C++

D.A.I.S.Y.

Daisy was my main summer project and my first experience with AI. the name DAISY stands for Developed Artificial Intelligence Yett (Again, names not that good). It is an AI bot that answers questions. I built the Text recognition algorithm and the capability to scrape the web and find answers.

Python C++ Swift

Fighting Robot

I had a phase last summer where I wanted to create a fighting robot; no questions, please. This is why I made a mockup for a 3D printed fighting robot that used only 4 motors and was controlled with a controller. Sadly, the project came to an end when it fell off the table.

Hardware Python

Portfolio Website

This website, Ta-Da! It is built using HTML, CSS, and JS. I've created this website portfolio after long nights of figuring out text-align and how to center a div. I've deepened my knowledge of the 3 languages and Git in the process.

HTML CSS JavaScript

); }; const About = () => { return (

Hi, I'm Abe Raouh

Software Engineer based in New York, NY

ML/AI enthusiast

); }; const Work = () => { return (

Work Experience

June 22 - August 22

Software Engineer Intern @ Mobiblanc

  • Developed a modular artificial intelligence customer support bot using DialogFlow on Google Cloud, implemented on 7 webpages using HTML and JavaScript. Connected the user inquiries to two MySQL databases, one which the bot automatically uses to answer user questions, and the other to add new inquiries for the team to look at.
  • Decreased wait time by over 70% and reduced costs by 45%. Averaged 4700 daily interactions and 130 daily inquiries

August 22 - Present

Vice President @ Google Developer Student Club

  • Serving as VP at the Google Developers Student Club, I lead the planning and execution of initiatives, ensuring a robust and purposeful approach to our tech-focused endeavors.
  • From workshops to competitive coding events, I meticulously organize and execute activities, creating engaging experiences that contribute to the club's vibrant atmosphere.

September 21 - Present

IT Specialist @ Fordham IT

  • Part-time position at Fordham IT's help desk, in which I assist members of the Fordham community with any of their tech issues, either in person or remotely.{" "}
  • I've learned to troubleshoot the various problems from the different scenarios I encountered, strengthening my skills and understanding of how the backend works.
  • This position also required constant interactions with IT specialists, supervisors, and other employees from different departments, thus improving my communication skills.

September 21 - August 22

Research Director @ Fordham Computer Science Society

  • In 2020, I was elected Research of the Forhdam Computer Science Society. I was in charge of most of weekly tech events organized by the Eboard, and researching the topics discussed. I was also in charge of keeping track of the club's inventory and leading a year long research project.

June 19 - July 19

Agent and Technician @ Moroccan Motorway Company

  • During the month-long internship, I maintained the hardware and software used by the agents in over 12 national agencies. The position required constant interactions with essential clients, appeasement of delicate situations between staff and clients, and a comfortable grasp of computer troubleshooting and hardware installations.

); }; const Research = () => { return (

Research Experience

Professor Mao, Fordham University

Quantum Computing, Deep Learning

  • Developed a multi-tenant quantum simulator for quantum deep learning application on a classical computer with Python and TensorFlow
  • Employed Qiskit APIs to analyze the workload distribution across individual qubits, gaining valuable efficiency in performance and capability which reduces development time by 3+ hours (depending on specific IBM-Q Computer)
  • Utilized Docker, Git, and Agile Scrum process to facilitate and accelerate the development process within the team

Professor Li, Fordham University

Image Segmentation Mathmatical Algorithms and Models

  • Implemented the iterative thresholding method for image segmentation using the Chan-Vese model in MATLAB and Python; incorporated convolution operations and region-specific information to enhance accuracy and achieve a 40% reduction in false positives
  • Utilized the results of the operation to accurately detect objects in an image at O(N logN) complexity
